title: 110_hr6308
content:
The "Municipal Bond Fairness Act" is also known as the "Discriminatory Ratings Treatment of State and Municipal Securities" Act. It aims to preserve the authority to prevent discrimination in the rating of state and municipal securities. Section 15E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include a new subsection (p) regarding Ratings Clarity and Consistency for nationally recognized statistical rating organizations. The Commission shall require these organizations to establish policies to assess the risk of investors not receiving payment for securities and money market instruments. The nationally recognized statistical rating organizations must establish policies to assess the risk of investors not receiving payment for securities and money market instruments. This includes defining rating symbols clearly and applying them consistently, as well as allowing the use of additional credit factors that impact investor risk. The Commission shall not impose restrictions on nationally recognized statistical rating organizations from considering unique credit factors for municipal securities not backed by full faith and credit in assessing investor repayment risk. Additionally, organizations can create complementary ratings to measure specific aspects of security or instrument risk. The Commission establishes performance measures for reviewing whether a rating organization adheres to its procedures for issuing ratings on securities or money market instruments. Performance measures considered include evidence in various categories outlined in the rules. The Commission determines performance measures for rating organizations, including transition and default rates in asset classes. SEC. 102. GENERAL ACCOUNTABILITY OFFICE STUDY OF CREDIT RATINGS. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the treatment of different classes of bonds by rating organizations, examining potential discrimination, causes of differences, factors beyond risk, municipal financing arrangements, and legal regulations. The Comptroller General will submit a report to the House of Representatives and the Senate within 6 months of the enactment of the Act. The report will assess issues such as differing legal regimes for corporate and municipal bonds, potential disadvantages for retail investors from a single ratings scale, and rating practices for municipal bonds by recognized organizations. SEC. 103. IMPLEMENTATION. The Securities and Exchange Commission will implement amendments within 270 days of the Act's enactment. TITLE II--REVIEW OF MUNICIPAL BOND INSURANCE INDUSTRY SEC. 201. AUTHORITY OF SECRETARY. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to collect and analyze data on entities insuring municipal obligations, including financial safety, insurance liabilities, performance under economic stress, underwriting standards, and risk management. The Secretary may voluntarily receive non-public data without waiving privilege or confidentiality. If data is already available to States or other sources, an information-sharing agreement may be made. Federal or State law requirements still apply. The Secretary must maintain confidentiality and privilege for any non-public data obtained from a source entitled to confidential treatment under applicable laws. The Secretary must maintain confidentiality and privilege for any non-public data obtained from a source entitled to confidential treatment under applicable laws, including personally identifiable information, trade secrets, and commercial or financial information. SEC. 202. REPORTS TO CONGRESS.

The Secretary must report annually to specific congressional committees on the financial state of the insurance and guarantee industry for municipal bonds, highlighting trends and potential impacts on the financial system.

SEC. 203. RETENTION OF REGULATORY AUTHORITY.

This title does not grant the Secretary supervisory authority over entities insuring or guaranteeing municipal obligations.

SEC. 204. DEFINITIONS. For the purposes of this title, a municipal obligation refers to any bond, note, security, or debt issued by a State, political subdivision, agency, or other eligible entity. Political subdivision includes cities, counties, towns, and townships. A "subdivision" refers to any general purpose or special purpose political entity within a State. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Treasury. The term "State" includes various territories and possessions of the United States. SEC. 205. Authorization of appropriations for the Secretary to carry out this title each fiscal year.
